thread.title: Cobra ready to reclaim Cobra 10s title after seven-year hiatus
thread.title_full: Cobra ready to reclaim Cobra 10s title after seven-year hiatus

title: Cobra ready to reclaim Cobra 10s title after seven-year hiatus
text:
Cobra ready to reclaim Cobra 10s title after seven-year hiatus Thursday October 8, 2015 Print Article 
Picture shows (from left) Cobra Rugby Club president, Lieutenant-Colonel Tommy Pereira, Cobra Rugby Club chairman, Tan Sri Krishnan, Tan Boon Seng and Rugby Team Cobra captain, Asraf Rosli Mohd Syahir posing with a new logo during the Cobra logo launch, Oct 8, 2015. — Bernama pic PETALING JAYA, Oct 8 — Cobra Rugby Club (Cobra) is ready to reclaim the Cobra 10s title when the invitational rugby tournament kicks off for two-days starting on Nov 7 at the the Petaling Jaya City Stadium, here. 
Cobra captain, Mohd Syahir Asyraf Rosli said the team is confident of wresting back the title in the 10-a-side competition they last won in 2008 based on thorough preparations they made the past few months, beside guidance from former All Blacks player, Duncan Ferguson of New Zealand. 
Mohd Syahir, who is also the national rugby team captain, said the confidence level to win the tournament was also high considering the team will be beefed up with several international players including from New Zealand, Australia and some regular Fijians besides a few national players such as Amin Jamaluddin and Hafiz Zainal. 
“We had reached the final for the past few years but luck was always not on our side. Hopefully, with the intensive training that we have gone through before this, it will help us wrest back the title,” he said. 
He was speaking to reporters after the announcement of the tournament by Cobra president, Lt Col (Rtd) Tommy Pereira, here, today. 
Meanwhile, Pereira said, the organiser had received confirmation from two South African teams and were still waiting for the decision from six other international teams especially from Australia and New Zealand which have been a regular feature in previous tournaments. 
He also noted besides eight foreign teams, eight local clubs will also vying for glory in the 45th edition of the tournament that has been held since 1967. 
“We are also fortunate that through our former President (Tan Sri Krishnan Tan) and few other Cobra members, we managed to establish a School Development Programme (for students) which has shown positive results in churning out more talented players at the grassroots level,” Pereira added. 
The winners and first runner-up in the first division (cup competition) will walk away with US$10,000 (RM42,231) and US$5,000 (RM21,115) respectively; the semi-finalists will pocket US$2,500 (RM10,556) each while the second division champions (plate competition) get US$1,000 (RM4,222). 
Cobra are Malaysia’s best performers in the annual tournament with six titles under their belt -- 1968, 1972, 1975, 1977 (sharing with Singapore’s Sembawang Tigers), 1998 and 2008. — Bernama
